Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Computational Design of Programmable Lattice Material Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Lattice materials can be engineered to exhibit desired bulk properties by controlling, through design and fabrication, the spatial arrangement of one or more base materials at smaller dimensional scales than the bulk material. Programmable materials are those that can change their spatial configuration in real-time, thereby offering the possibility of attaining not one but a number of desired behaviors. The proxy programmable material system considered in this research consists of a truss lattice with struts that can be opened and closed by means of electromagnetic joints. To attain multiple desired properties, it is necessary to determine both the lattice design, consisting of the size and position of the struts, and a program corresponding to each property consisting of the open/closed state of the joints. This effort, however, involves a large number of design parameters, hence it is not possible in general to design and program these materials by mere intuition, nor is it feasible to resort to computational, let alone experimental trial-and-error. This Design of Engineering Material Systems (DEMS) award supports fundamental research to formulate the first computational framework for the systematic design and programming of these lattice material systems. Results of this research have potentially far reaching applications, such as adaptable remote infrastructure operating in inhospitable environments, shelters that adapt their response to the direction of an incoming impact, building foundations that respond to the direction and frequency of an incoming seismic wave to avoid resonance, or aircraft wing structures that adapt to the flight regime to decrease drag and increase fuel efficiency. A concerted effort to recruit underrepresented undergraduate and graduate students for this project will increase their participation in the field of computational materials design. The multidisciplinary nature of this research will allow them to conduct research in a highly collaborative environment and ultimately widen their career opportunities.

The foundation of the design framework is the projection of an analytical geometry representation of the lattice beams onto a fixed finite element grid for analysis and topology optimization. The intellectual contributions of this research lie in the ability to project the beams with electromagnetic joints to obtain an analysis model whose accuracy is adequate for the design, combine geometric requirements with strength, stability and connectivity constraints to ensure the lattice can be fabricated and does not lose its specified functions and simultaneously design the lattice and determine the programs necessary to attain multiple functions by solving a bi-level optimization problem.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

 

Novel additive manufacturing techniques are increasingly facilitating the fabrication of lightweight porous materials with superior mechanical properties in which the distribution of the constituent material phases is carefully controlled. Some of these architected materials achieve performance-to-weight ratios not achievable in natural or man-made bulk materials, thus they are called metamaterials. A particular type of architected metamaterials is periodic truss lattices, which are made of a repeating unit cell that contains slender elements such as struts. These lattices thus resemble building scaffolding and roof trusses; however, the struts diameters and lengths are in the micron and millimeter scale. Architected truss lattices have an open unit cell that easily allows for the removal of support material in the fabrication, therefore they have a significant potential in their application to the design of lightweight structural components.

This research produced computational techniques to efficiently design architected truss lattices for superior performance-to-weight ratios. These design techniques determine the optimal spatial layout of the struts within the unit cell of the lattice. An optimization method takes an initial design of struts and changes the dimensions and positions of each strut, or altogether removes struts, to maximize some mechanical performance measure such as stiffness subject to a constraint on the amount of material that can be used. As the connectivity or topology of the lattices changes during the optimization, these computational design techniques belong to the realm of structural topology optimization.

A significant product of this research is a topology optimization technique to design lattices in which each strut can be made of one of a set of candidate materials. The optimization simultaneously determines the optimal layout of struts and the optimal choice of material for each strut. These multi-material lattices can achieve better performance-to-weight ratios than lattices made solely of one of the candidate materials.  Another outcome of this research is a technique to design lattices in which the struts are, for example, hollow or fiber-reinforced, in which case the mechanical properties of the strut are direction-dependent. These lattices are not subject to theoretical bounds on the mechanical properties of multiphase materials in which the properties of each of the constituent phases are orientation-independent and therefore, as shown by our research, they can attain significantly higher stiffness-to-weight ratios.

Finally, another significant product is a topology optimization technique to design so-called programmable lattices, whereby individual struts can be actuated by some means (e.g., electromagnetic, fluidic or thermal) so that they are effectively open or closed in service. A particular combination of open/closed states for the struts in the unit cell (i.e., a program) leads to a different effective behavior of the lattice. The computational design technique advanced in this research simultaneously determines the optimal layout of the struts and two or more programs to obtain desired target properties. For instance, a programmable lattice can be engineered with this design technique to exhibit two target stiffness values corresponding to two different actuation programs with a constraint on the amount of material that can be used in the design.

The lattice structures that can be designed with the computational techniques produced by this research have a wide range of potential applications, for example in the design of lightweight structural components for aerospace applications to reduce fuel consumption, as infills in orthopedic implants where it is desired to match the stiffness of the surrounding bone, and in structures where different mechanical behaviors are desired in different operating conditions such as flight regimes and ambient temperatures.

This project also supported the successful completion of a doctoral dissertation and the publication of multiple journal manuscripts. Results of this research have been incorporated in curriculum development and in outreach summer activities for K-12 teachers.

Modified by: Julian Norato
